items.title: Awakenings, 1990 - ★★★
items.content_html: 🍿
items.content_text:
This astonishing and heartwarming story, based on true events, highlights the importance of maintaining hope against all odds. It also explores what fair conditions are necessary for a proper life. The acting is remarkable, with Robert De Niro displaying incredible physical ability as he portrays a patient suffering from full-body spasms. The secondary characters also deliver impressive performances. I was particularly struck by the nurse, played by Julie Kavner, who was beginning her journey to fame as the voice of Marge Simpson at that time. Bonus points for the soundtrack featuring The Zombies' Time of the Season and Jimi Hendrix’s Purple Haze. And for featuring Kevin McCallister’s dad and The Ghostbusters' librarian.

— We call this place the garden.

— Why?

— Because all we do is feed and water them.

🍿

Les appels et messages indésirables sur téléphone sont nombreux. Voici quelques conseils qui m’ont permis de me protéger :

  1. Je me suis inscrit sur Bloctel1;
  2. J’ai installé Orange Téléphone sur mon iPhone, qui marque certains appels comme “⚠️ Télémarketing” ou “❌ Indésirable”;
  3. Je signale tout ce qui continue à m’arriver sur 337002.

🏛️ × 🧘‍♂️

  1. un service du gouvernement français qui permet d’appliquer la “loi n° 2014-344 du 17 mars 2014 relative à la consommation, permettant à toute personne de refuser d’être démarchée par un professionnel avec lequel elle n’a pas de relation contractuelle en cours” ↩︎

  2. un service de l’af2m (Association Française pour le Développement des services et usages Multimédias Multi-opérateurs), qui regroupe entre autres les opérateurs mobiles français ↩︎
items.content_text:
Les appels et messages indésirables sur téléphone sont nombreux. Voici quelques conseils qui m'ont permis de me protéger :

1. Je me suis inscrit sur [Bloctel](https://www.bloctel.gouv.fr/)[^1];
2. J'ai installé [Orange Téléphone](https://apps.apple.com/fr/app/orange-phone/id1441313724?l=fr-FR) sur mon iPhone, qui marque certains appels comme "⚠️ Télémarketing" ou "❌ Indésirable";
3. Je signale tout ce qui continue à m'arriver sur [33700](https://www.33700.fr/)[^2].

🏛️ × 🧘‍♂️

[^1]: un service du gouvernement français qui permet d'appliquer la "loi n° 2014-344 du 17 mars 2014 relative à la consommation, **permettant à toute personne de refuser** d'être démarchée par un professionnel avec lequel elle n'a pas de relation contractuelle en cours"

[^2]: un service de l'af2m (Association Française pour le Développement des services et usages Multimédias Multi-opérateurs), qui regroupe entre autres les opérateurs mobiles français

items.title: Migration, 2023 - ★★★★
items.content_html: <!-- raw HTML omitted -->
items.content_text: A fun family movie! While the plot offers no major surprises, it remains enjoyable and entertaining. I even noticed a wink to Zoolander's Mugatu (or maybe that's just my obsession with Will Ferrell speaking) and Home Alone 2 (pigeons with an arch in the background in Central Park), so bonus points for that! I'm a bit scared to rewatch it with my wife because she might say, “Mick is such a Mack” (I am). As for the kids, they might decide never to eat birds again. Note to self: I’ve never tried canard à l'orange; I should! 🍿

items.title: Everything Everywhere All at Once, 2022 - ★★★★
items.content_html: <!-- raw HTML omitted -->
items.content_text: This is my second time watching the film. The first time was at the movie theater, where I fell asleep and woke up confused, unsure of what I had just seen. This time, I watched it at home, breaking it into four or five segments. Again, I dozed off during each part. However, I appreciated the ability to pause and resume the next day. I realized that this movie is 100% a comedy, rather than a family drama about a broken relationship between a mother, her husband, and their daughter. It cleverly weaves fun into these family issues, making them vague enough for everyone to relate to on some level of "what if…?". I enjoyed it much more this time around. 🍿

items.content_html:
Jolie vidéo de la marque Asphalte :

Produire, c’est utiliser des ressources mais on refuse de laisser les marques qui ne font aucun effort gagner cette bataille, parce que si on arrête, elles continuent de cramer la planète à toute vitesse. Alors on reste, on se bat, et on innove.

Depuis quelques années, quand j’ai besoin d’un vêtement, je l’achète chez Asphalte, Seagale, Le Slip Français, ou Archiduchesse. Mais c’est bien Asphalte qui est le plus clair sur l’importance des pièces intemporelles qui durent longtemps.

Grâce à eux, j’ai une garde robe suffisante, et je n’aurai besoin de rien pour plusieurs mois. C’est le paradoxe : parce qu’ils bossent bien, j’ai de moins en moins besoin d’eux. Mais la planète si. À vous de jouer désormais.

🌱

items.title: Disney Finds $100M for Stephen A. Smith, But Not a Dime for FiveThirtyEight
items.content_html:
FiveThirtyEight has shut down.

Its founder, Nate Silver:

Last night, as President Trump delivered his State of the Union address1, the Wall Street Journal reported that ABC News would lay off the remaining staff at 538 as part of broader cuts within corporate parent Disney.

John Gruber expressed frustration about the site not remaining online in an archive state:

But the standard behavior when closing a web publication is to just pull the plug. When the whole company goes under, that’s one thing. But when there’s a parent company, especially a thriving one, there’s no justification for pulling the plug other than spiteful disregard for the work. From the perspective of a company the size of Disney, it would cost veritable pennies to keep FiveThirtyEight’s website around forever. What a disgrace.

I could not agree more. I relied heavily on the site for my past attempts to start a company and my current confidential side project as a data soccer analyst. Which made me feel sad and disappointed about FiveThirtyEight’s fate.

And then this:

Stephen A. Smith has agreed to a new contract with ESPN worth at least $100 million for five years, an agreement that will result in Smith continuing to star on “First Take” on ESPN while scaling back some of his other required appearances on the network, which would free him up to talk even more about politics, sources briefed on the agreement told The Athletic.

This is driving me mad. The coincidence of these two events reflects capitalism at its worst: promoting fast-paced, nonsensical, emotionally-driven rants over data-driven analysis. The only thing I appreciate about Smith — or many other similar pundits — is its hilarious caricature by the Simpsons.

🏀 × ⚽️ × 🏛️
items.content_text:
FiveThirtyEight has shut down.

Its founder, [Nate Silver](https://www.natesilver.net/p/a-few-words-about-fivethirtyeight):

> Last night, as President Trump delivered his State of the Union address[1](https://www.natesilver.net/p/a-few-words-about-fivethirtyeight#footnote-1-158462587), the Wall Street Journal [reported](https://www.wsj.com/business/media/disney-to-cut-nearly-6-staff-across-abc-news-disney-entertainment-networks-8af04b40) that ABC News would lay off the remaining staff at 538 as part of broader cuts within corporate parent Disney.

[John Gruber expressed frustration about the site not remaining online in an archive state](https://daringfireball.net/2025/03/abc_shuts_down_fivethirtyeight):

> But the standard behavior when closing a web publication is to just pull the plug. When the whole company goes under, that's one thing. But when there's a parent company, especially a thriving one, there's no justification for pulling the plug other than spiteful disregard for the work. From the perspective of a company the size of Disney, it would cost veritable pennies to keep FiveThirtyEight's website around forever. What a disgrace.

I could not agree more. I relied heavily on the site for my past attempts to start a company and my current confidential side project as a data soccer analyst. Which made me feel sad and disappointed about FiveThirtyEight's fate.

And then [this](https://www.nytimes.com/athletic/6181819/2025/03/06/stephen-a-smith-contract-espn-first-take/):

> Stephen A. Smith has agreed to a new contract with ESPN worth at least $100 million for five years, an agreement that will result in Smith continuing to star on "First Take" on ESPN while scaling back some of his other required appearances on the network, which would free him up to talk even more about politics, sources briefed on the agreement told _The Athletic._

This is driving me mad. The coincidence of these two events reflects capitalism at its worst: promoting fast-paced, nonsensical, emotionally-driven rants over data-driven analysis. The only thing I appreciate about Smith — or many other similar pundits — is [its hilarious caricature by the Simpsons](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OpHR3jmNjqQ).

🏀 × ⚽️ × 🏛️

items.content_html:
I am not a frequent user of Instagram. I visit occasionally because some of my favorite people and places only post there. I noticed that the platform has shifted from square previews to rectangle previews. If I were a heavy user, this change would have driven me crazy. I remember how some people used to be creative with their posts, creating really cool feeds filled with square previews. Instagram threw away all that effort.

Instagram users: it’s never too late to leave. Pixelfed — or Micro.blog — are very solid fediverse alternatives.

💻

items.title: Asterix: The Secret of the Magic Potion, 2018 - ★★★★
items.content_html: <!-- raw HTML omitted -->
items.content_text: Astier remet le couvert pour une adaptation encore plus réussie que Le Domaine des Dieux. Il aborde subtilement le thème de la mort, de la transmission et même des choses plus poétiques comme “est-ce que tout ce qu’on fait doit être utile”. Du Kaamelott pour enfant, avec un vocabulaire qui sera un peu complexe pour les moins de 6 ans. 🍿

items.content_html: Piratatak est un jeu assez faiblard. À éviter si on n’est pas du genre à faire exprès de laisser gagner les enfants car une stratégie de base — remettre les cartes des bateaux adverses dans la pioche — rendra le jeu interminable et très ennuyant. Il faudrait sans doute modifier les règles pour rendre le truc intéressant. 🎮

items.title: Frozen II, 2019 - ★★★★
items.content_html: <!-- raw HTML omitted -->
items.content_text: I know some people may not think it’s cool to say this, but I love the Frozen series. The characters, humor, atmosphere, visuals, and, of course, the music are all top-notch. I’m lucky to watch the original version with my kids because the few scenes I have seen from the French version really fall short. It’s a family favorite with a high rewatchability factor and we can’t wait for the 3rd episode. There, I said it. 🍿

items.title: Spider-Man: Across the Spider-Verse, 2023 - ★★★★
items.content_html: <!-- raw HTML omitted -->
items.content_text: Spider-Man: Across the Spider-Verse is visually striking and stunning, making it nearly overwhelming. It offers a unique experience filled with laughter and emotional moments driven by poignant, albeit excessive, teenage angst. A quick spoiler alert: the film concludes with a cliffhanger and a To be continued notice, which has not yet been released. Therefore, if you require a story resolution, there’s no rush to watch this movie. 🍿

items.title: Final Set, 2020 - ★★★
items.content_html: Dans Guy, Alex Lutz créait déjà un personnage qui en mélangeait pleins (Sardou, Claude François, Belmondo, etc.). Ici, on a un mélange de Richard Gasquet, Paul-Henri Mathieu, etc. ie un petit génie du tennis qui ne confirme pas, avec ici un potard lose bien plus accentué que ses modèles, car eux ont fait des belles carrières malgré tout. Roland-Garros fait presque partie des personnages. La dernière partie du film m’a rappelé le final de Bohemian Rhapsody, où on voit les personnages exercer leur art in extenso, en version cinéma. Chouette petit film. 🍿

items.content_html:
Super vidéo : un mashup des lives du SNL, qui sert de teaser pour un documentaire intitulé 50 Years of SNL Music. On y retrouve Franz Ferdinand, Run DMC, Hanson, Queen, Fun Lovin’ Criminals, et bien d’autres encore (liste non exhaustive d’ordre d’apparition pendant que je tape ceci). Côté introductions et invités, il y a des acteurs, des sportifs…

Plusieurs tentatives ont été faites pour créer une version française du SNL — Les Nuls, l’émission, Samedi soir en direct —, mais aucune n’a duré plus de quelques saisons. À quoi cette vidéo ressemblerait-elle si nous avions eu un SNL à la française pendant 50 ans ?

🎵 × 🍿

items.content_html: Finished watching Silo season 1. It was great. After many people from my feeds recommended it, I finally gave in, and it did not disappoint. The plot, characters, cast, acting, atmosphere, and decor are all amazing. The episodes are the perfect length (about 40 minutes). My only reservation is the music; while the main theme is pretty cool, the background music during scenes feels a bit too on the nose for my tastes. But I might be being overly critical. Now, onward to season 2! 🍿

items.title: That Christmas, 2024 - ★★★★
items.content_html: How was I supposed to tell my kids that the Christmas movie season was over after watching Die Hard a couple of days ago? Written by Richard Curtis, who also directed Love Actually, this film humorously pokes fun at the genre. It is sweet and heartfelt, making me tear up about four or five times. I highly recommend it. 🍿

items.content_html:
Henry Rich on the R!sky Business podcast, about climate change:

I’m pivoting to more focus on this book on individual action and building climate identity as a consumer. […] I think a lot of the meaning of one’s life as you look back in it will be what individual parts they played in this massive success or catastrophic failure. […] The risk of looking back and not liking what I see is haunting for me. And I also think that there’s a lot of low grade anxiety that people feel about not the threat, but the paralysis. So trying to create tools and heuristics for people to actually tap into something to feel good about and not just feel low key sleepwalking toward armageddon.

I have a strong feeling that when I eventually move away from software engineering, I would love to open a sustainable bar or restaurant that fosters a strong sense of community. Bookmarking this for that time, and waiting for the book.

Also take a look at the restaurants Henry is running. They look gorgeous.

🌱

items.content_html:
Mattt:

op lets you manage 1Password from the command-line. (…) Its killer features is the op run subcommand, which can dynamically inject secrets from your 1Password vault into your application’s environment. Instead of storing sensitive values directly in your .env file, you reference them using special op:// URLs.

Smart. Replacing secrets by references also means that backups are easier. I also wonder if we could define a URL scheme for keychain items URL instead of op to fetch secrets. 💻
items.content_text:
[Mattt](https://nshipster.com/1password-cli/):

> `op` lets you manage 1Password from the command-line. (…) Its killer features is the `op run` subcommand, which can dynamically inject secrets from your 1Password vault into your application's environment. Instead of storing sensitive values directly in your `.env` file, you reference them using special `op://` URLs.

Smart. Replacing secrets by references also means that backups are easier. I also wonder if we could define a URL scheme for keychain items URL instead of `op` to fetch secrets. 💻

items.title: Apprendre à ranger une sale vide
items.content_html:
Alors évidemment, le “consulting”, c’est comme tout, ça dépend comment c’est fait. Mais comment ne pas sourire et se rappeler des souvenirs de début de carrière quand on entend :

De temps en temps, il y avait des consultants qui venaient et qui expliquaient pourquoi il fallait virer untel, faire des économies là. Un mec qui était à son poste depuis 25 ans, ils lui disaient “non, c’est pas comme ça qu’il faut travailler monsieur”. C’était quand même à la fois violent et universel comme phénomène, ils étaient partout. Et puis après j’ai travaillé dans des organismes publics, ils étaient toujours là. Et ils faisaient la même chose, il faut faire des économies, il faut faire des gains d’efficacité, la performance. Et puis alors ce langage, ce langage avec plein d’anglicismes et puis ce langage expert qui exerce un pouvoir. Et comme des millions de français, je l’ai subi. Et ça s’exerce comme une science, comme les économistes un peu, ils pensent que c’est une science. Et donc c’est un discours qui est sans réplique quand on y est, sauf qu’après on peut écrire des livres. Et là on peut se venger. Alors vous dites avec un certain amusement, mais aussi avec pas mal d’ironie et la volonté de ridiculiser ces pouvoirs faussement savants. La littérature, voilà, elle a toujours à faire avec la bêtise de son temps. Le consulting, il y en a de mille manières. Donc il y a des choses plus ou moins vertueuses, des choses plus ou moins bidons. Alors j’en ai quand même rencontré des consultants. J’ai lu des livres, des consultants repentis, certains qui travaillaient encore, etc. Et il y a des phrases… “Être consultant, c’est prendre sa montre à quelqu’un pour lui donner l’heure et partir avec la montre”. Voilà. Enfin voilà, il faut raconter tout ça quand même. C’est apprendre à ranger une sale vide aussi ? Ah oui, alors ça oui, un consultant qui m’a dit ça, bah oui c’était apprendre à ranger une sale vide.

— Nicolas Mathieu, lors d’une interview dans la librairie Dialogues, à Brest

🏛️ × 🍿

items.title: I got a new backpack
items.content_html:
I got a new backpack to replace my Timbuk2 Q Laptop Backpack, which I had been using since 2012. It’s showing its age: the inner net has a big hole, I stitched up a tear in the nylon top, and all the zippers are starting to deteriorate with aging threads.

So, it was time for a new one. I opted for another Timbuk2 backpack, the Authority Laptop Backpack Deluxe, which Wirecutter recommends.

I feel a bit sad that it doesn’t have the bottle opener that my 31-year-old self was so excited about, but I hope it lasts another 12 years or more.

🌱

items.content_html:
Spotify drives me crazy with its song shuffle functionality. For example, the Apple TV app does not include a shuffle option. Instead, it applies the shuffle setting from other versions of the app you may be using. This is quite maddening.

My ideal shuffle behavior would be the following:

  1. Never defaulting to shuffle tracks for albums. I prefer to listen to complete albums in their intended order. Who doesn’t?
  2. Implementing a per-playlist shuffle setting. Some of my shorter playlists have a specific order, while I only use shuffle for the longer ones.

🎵 × 💻

YouTube tends to transcribe “ChatGPT” as “Chachi BT”. Funny.

When you search for “Chachi BT” on Google, there are so many results and pretty much all of them are indeed about ChatGPT. Meaning that no human edited the posts before publication to fix this typo even in titles, meta tags, etc. Scary.

🍿× 💻

items.content_html:
Je fais ce truc de Mary Kondo où tu dois mettre tous tes bouquins par terre pour trier/jeter.

Si tu me demandes si je suis une personne qui a la lecture au corps, je dirais probablement non, intimidé par rapport à ceux qui ont déjà lu Émile Zola ou Victor Hugo, ce qui n’est pas mon cas.

Mais en fait, peut-être bien que j’en suis. Astérix, Gotlib, France Football, Mickey Parade, les Inrocks, Rock&Folk et quelques auteurs — quand même — m’ont accompagné jusqu’aux 43 piges. Est-ce que ça compte ? Est-ce que ça se transmet ? Est-ce que ça se jette ? Je suis face à un gouffre existentiel. Vous en pensez quoi vous ?

🧘

I just finished watching Modern Family.

For about five years, it’s been a constant part of our routine when my wife and I have lunch together at home. The last time we watched the show, Season 11—the final season—wasn’t available in France, so we rewatched the entire series. Now, we’ve finally completed Season 11. It was an emotional moment, both on screen and in our living room.

I’m not sure why it’s not more popular among our friends, but for me, it’s definitely in my hall of fame. 🍿

items.content_html:
I just finished watching Bad Monkey on Apple TV+. It was really good and I highly recommend it.

Some notes:

  • The showrunner, Bill Lawrence, who was also behind Ted Lasso and Shrinking delivered again. The Ringer has a piece about him;
  • Eve Stripling is easily one of the most compelling villains I’ve seen in a while;
  • The soundtrack is spot-on and adds so much to the vibe;
  • The “good guys” are all super charming and relatable;
  • It’s based on a novel by Carl Hiaasen, and it feels like it shares the same DNA as the works of Laurent Chalumeau — both clearly influenced by the legendary Elmore Leonard.

🍿

Big thanks to Manton Reece for pointing me to this hilarious bit by John Mulaney about captchas.

It’s now up there with Michael McIntyre’s sketch on passwords in the hall of fame of tech-related comedy. 💻 × 🍿

items.content_html:
Naming things is quite famously one of the hardest problems in software development.

When you realize there is a better name for something, it’s important to rename it, even if it’s tricky. Clear, accurate names improve the developer experience, while bad names make maintenance harder, slower, and riskier. Leaving sub-optimal names in a codebase is technical debt. 💻

items.title: A simple workflow for translation keys typed with TypeScript
items.content_html:
Since my web projects use typed translation keys, my work in progress would typically add unwanted TypeScript errors every time I added a new translation key, and that would annoy me a lot.

So I wrote a little script that watches a temporary JSON translation file (as used by Lokalise) and merges it into all the translation files of the languages that are supported every time it changes.

This way, once I am done with a feature, I can upload the new keys all at once in Lokalise’s upload tool. 💻

items.title: Apple Event 2024: Carbon Footprint of the iPhone 16 Series
items.content_html:
I recently watched the 2024 Apple Event, where they briefly discussed their efforts toward carbon neutrality by 2030. While the event touched on Apple’s sustainable packaging initiatives, their website provides more detailed information on the environmental impact of their products.

Here’s what I found about the carbon footprint of the latest iPhones:

  • The iPhone 16 Pro Max 256 Go has a carbon footprint of 74 kg.
  • The iPhone 16 Plus 128 Go has a carbon footprint of 60 kg.

Quite better than the Apple Vision Pro.

If you’re interested in learning more about Apple’s progress toward sustainability and carbon neutrality, their website offers comprehensive details. It’s worth considering how these efforts align with their 2030 environmental goals.

💻

items.title: How to Remove YouTube Controls from a Paused Video for Better Screenshots
items.content_html:
If you’ve ever tried to take a clean screenshot from a paused YouTube video, you’ve probably noticed the overlay controls and gradient at the bottom of the screen that get in the way. Fortunately, there’s a simple solution using JavaScript in the browser console:

The steps to remove YouTube controls are:

  1. Pause the video at the frame you want to capture.
  2. Open the browser console (typically by pressing F12 or Ctrl + Shift + I).
  3. Run the following JavaScript code to remove the bottom gradient and control bar:
document.querySelector(".ytp-gradient-bottom").remove()
document.querySelector(".ytp-chrome-bottom").remove()

After running this, the video controls and gradient will disappear, allowing you to take a clean screenshot of the paused video.

💻
items.content_text:
If you've ever tried to take a clean screenshot from a paused YouTube video, you've probably noticed the overlay controls and gradient at the bottom of the screen that get in the way. Fortunately, there's a simple solution using JavaScript in the browser console:

The steps to remove YouTube controls are:

1. **Pause the video** at the frame you want to capture.
2. **Open the browser console** (typically by pressing `F12` or `Ctrl + Shift + I`).
3. **Run the following JavaScript code** to remove the bottom gradient and control bar:


```js
document.querySelector(".ytp-gradient-bottom").remove()
document.querySelector(".ytp-chrome-bottom").remove()
```

After running this, the video controls and gradient will disappear, allowing you to take a clean screenshot of the paused video.

💻

items.content_html:
On the UK willing to be a clean energy superpower

Thank you Keir Starmer.

It takes courage for governments to advance their climate change agenda because it impacts people both economically—likely destroying some jobs in the short term—and personally, as changing habits is a difficult process.

In a slightly longer term, by 2050, for example, failing to make progress will hurt people significantly more.

It is reassuring that in the UK, climate change is a concern across a large section of the political spectrum. It is not surprising that parties genuinely caring for most people have bolder objectives.

It is also not surprising that far-right leaders do not care. They prioritize power over people. The only traits I can think of that would lead someone to deny the need for climate action are selfishness, cowardice and ignorance. Not the best traits.

🏛️

items.content_html:
This interview with Lori Gottlieb by Jon Stewart helps me realize my political anxiety is normal and that I should try to make it productive. But what can I do?

  • Get involved in a campaign? Writing my thoughts is as far as I can go. Whenever I tried joining a political group, its internal politics and strategics were repulsive to me.
  • Volunteer? I just found a program to help kids with homework, via jeveuxaider.gouv.fr that I didn’t know about.
  • Vote? ✅
  • Encourage people around you to vote? ✅

It still feels like not enough.

Also, Jon is hilarious:

My anxiety has never saved me from bears, but it often convinces me I’m not lovable.

🏛️

This evening, i was forced to watch _The Idea of You_. At the beginning of the movie, before Solène enters Hayes' trailer, I wrote this:

> She's gonna date a Moon.

items.title: Thoughts about the state of web tooling
items.content_html:
I spent some time yesterday evening with a starter template of Remix + Vite. Here are a few thoughts:

  • I couldn’t figure out how to import CSS. The Remix documentation referred to Vite’s, which was technology-agnostic and suggested that importing CSS should be straightforward. However, my attempts failed. When simple tasks become difficult, I understand the strange popularity of Tailwind.
  • Vercel has its own package to run Remix, leading Remix to remove their Vercel starter template from their repository. From an outside perspective, it seems ego battles are harming the developer experience.
  • Sass seems to be considered outdated compared to all the PostCSS options.

I still believe the web is moving towards some consolidation among tools, but it’s very frustrating right now. 💻

items.title: Asteroid City, 2023 - ★★★
items.content_html: <!-- raw HTML omitted -->
items.content_text:
Wes Anderson’s “Asteroid City”’s rhythm is frenetic, and it's hard to find time to breathe. I had heard that it was a bit over the top, even for Wes Anderson fans, and it is indeed true. However, the lighting is spectacular, and I think the images will stay forever in the minds of those who see it.

The film addresses loneliness, being an outcast, and how different scales of life impact each other: from personal to communal, national, or even cosmic levels. Individuals have little control over threats like nuclear war, quarantines, or UFO interventions, or even over how to grieve, both individually and collectively. It emphasizes that everyone has a role to play at every level, encapsulated in the final mantra, "You can't wake up if you don't fall asleep." This suggests that being perpetually active and busy might prevent us from seeing the bigger picture of our intentions with our lives or the impact we can have on challenging the absurdities of our Western governments.

Wes Anderson's usual magic lies in his movies being so rich in details that they offer a new experience with each viewing. They create a framework where your attention can explore different details each time. "Asteroid City" seems to be no exception, and I look forward to watching it again.

items.content_html:
Note: same as this post, this time in French.

The Athletic se demande comment savoir si un coach est bon à son poste. L’article est hyper intéressant et arrive à 2 conclusions. Un, la qualité des joueurs compte pour environ 80% des résultats. Deux, les bonnes ou mauvaises performances d’un coach dans une équipe dans les 20% qui restent ne prédisent en rien ses résultats dans son prochain club.

Dès lors, la bonne question semble être quel est le bon coach pour tel groupe de joueurs. Et à ce jeu-là, Eric Roy (Brest) et Sebastian Hoeness (Stuttgart) dominent largement le Big 5 cette saison.

#255 ⚽️
items.content_text:
_Note: same as [this post](https://dirtyhenry.micro.blog/2024/04/08/eric-roy-dominates.html), this time in French._

The Athletic se demande [comment savoir si un coach est bon à son poste](https://theathletic.com/5392417/2024/04/07/good-manager-how-to-tell/). L’article est hyper intéressant et arrive à 2 conclusions. Un, la qualité des joueurs compte pour [environ 80% des résultats](https://app-statium.eu-central-1.linodeobjects.com/player-quality.png). Deux, les bonnes ou mauvaises performances d’un coach dans une équipe dans les 20% qui restent ne prédisent en rien ses résultats dans son prochain club. 

Dès lors, la bonne question semble être quel est le bon coach pour tel groupe de joueurs. Et à ce jeu-là, Eric Roy (Brest) et Sebastian Hoeness (Stuttgart) [dominent largement](https://app-statium.eu-central-1.linodeobjects.com/top-15-this-season.png) le Big 5 cette saison. 

[#255](https://www.statium.app/newsletter/posts/newsletter-255) ⚽️

À mon avis, Henry David aimait le foot.

Quand des joueurs sortent la tête du trou, comme en ce moment avec la résurgence de l’OM avec Gasset ou la renaissance de Sancho à Dortmund, je me rappelle de la punchline que Jacques Monclar avait lâché sur le plateau de NBA Extra : “les joueurs ne sont pas des machines à laver”. Leur succès ou leur échec dépendent largement de leur environnement, du contexte et parfois même de la chance. Pendant ce temps, la plupart des joueurs de Chelsea sont réglés sur programme laine.

#247 ⚽️

Bravo à Lyon, Rennes et Valenciennes, qui se sont qualifiés pour les demi-finales de Coupe de France. L’Inter se rapproche du titre en Série A, en comptant 12 points d’avance. La tête de la Premier League est serrée comme rarement. Nous somme en mars, et comme souvent, l’odeur du money time émerge. Dans 3 mois tout rond, la saison se finira pour les clubs avec la Finale de la Ligue des Champions et il faudra laisser place aux sélections, sans Paul Pogba. Dommage.

items.content_html:
Cette semaine, L’Équipe consacre une série sur La révolution IA. Pour être dans le thème, j’ai demandé à ChatGPT comment se comporter quand on est souvent le meilleur joueur de l’équipe, et que le coache décide de nous remplacer. Sa réponse :

  • Respectez la décision du coach
  • Acceptez le rôle d’équipe
  • Encouragez vos coéquipiers sur le terrain
  • Restez concentré même sur le banc
  • Discutez avec le coach après le match si nécessaire

Merci le foot. #243 ⚽️

items.content_html:
Il y a quelques semaines, je parlais de la VAR. Cette semaine, la Premier League a aussi fait le point en insistant sur le fait que, selon elle, la VAR fonctionne puisque le taux de mauvaises décisions arbitrales est passé de 18% à 4%, en concédant qu’il fallait améliorer la fan experience.

Point par point :

  • Trop lent. L’idée ici est d’utiliser un système semi-automatique de détection des hors-jeu. OK, attendons de voir.
  • Trop opaque. Ouvrir le micro des arbitres est souhaité par la Premier League, mais empêché par les lois du football établies par l’IFAB. Donc, créer des cartons bleus c’est envisageable, mais donner une voix aux arbitres, c’est non. Sans avoir la raison du pourquoi, c’est une posture qui me semble compliquée à défendre.
  • Trop arbitraire. Là dessus, l’IFAB est intransigeante : ”Étant donné que chaque décision/incident sera vérifié, les entraîneurs ou les joueurs n’ont pas à demander une vérification ou une analyse.” Là, ça commence à se mordre la queue entre exhaustivité des vérifications, opacité et lenteur.

Bref, ça bosse, mais faut faire vite, car y’en a qui ont mis le pied dans la porte.

#238 ⚽️
items.content_text:
Il y a quelques semaines, [je parlais de la VAR](https://www.statium.app/newsletter/posts/newsletter-233). Cette semaine, [la Premier League a aussi fait le point](https://theathletic.com/5258531/2024/02/07/premier-league-var-briefing/) en insistant sur le fait que, selon elle, la VAR fonctionne puisque le taux de mauvaises décisions arbitrales est passé de 18% à 4%, en concédant qu'il fallait améliorer la _fan experience_.

Point par point :
* **Trop lent.** L'idée ici est d'utiliser un système semi-automatique de détection des hors-jeu. OK, attendons de voir.
* **Trop opaque.** Ouvrir le micro des arbitres est souhaité par la Premier League, mais empêché par les lois du football établies par l'IFAB. Donc, créer [des cartons bleus](https://www.lequipe.fr/Football/Actualites/Un-nouveau-carton-avec-suspension-temporaire-va-etre-teste/1447595) c'est envisageable, mais donner une voix aux arbitres, c'est non. Sans avoir la raison du pourquoi, c'est une posture qui me semble compliquée à défendre. 
* **Trop arbitraire.** Là dessus, l'IFAB est [intransigeante](https://www.theifab.com/fr/laws/latest/video-assistant-referee-var-protocol/#procedures) : ”Étant donné que chaque décision/incident sera vérifié, les entraîneurs ou les joueurs n'ont pas à demander une vérification ou une analyse.” Là, ça commence à se mordre la queue entre exhaustivité des vérifications, opacité et lenteur.

Bref, ça bosse, mais faut faire vite, car y'en a qui ont mis [le pied dans la porte](https://www.sofoot.com/breves/lenorme-somme-que-la-superligue-reclamerait-a-luefa). 

[#238](https://www.statium.app/newsletter/posts/newsletter-238) ⚽️

items.title: How much the Apple Vision Pro costs… environmentally
items.content_html:
The carbon footprint of an Apple Vision Pro amounts to 335kg of greenhouse gas emissions, slightly higher than the 300kg emitted by the 16-inch MacBook Pro I currently use. This represents approximately 15% of a yearly emissions budget of 2 tons, or about 3% when depreciated over a 5-year period.

As a programmer specializing in Apple technologies, I am naturally curious about the Apple Vision Pro. However, I have decided against purchasing one, not primarily due to financial constraints, but because I believe its environmental impact exceeds what is justifiable for a product that remains largely nonessential.

For numerous reasons, I hope the Apple Vision Pro fails to gain traction. However, it seems unlikely. Therefore, I urge you to consider its environmental cost as seriously as its monetary expense before making a purchasing decision. Please aim to offset emissions elsewhere, just as you would seek to save money in other areas if you choose to acquire one.

💻

This represents approximately 15% of a yearly emissions budget of 2 tons, or about 3% when depreciated over a 5-year period.

items.content_html:
I gave swift-openapi-generator a try to interact with Apple’s own App Store Connect API. The result was… unconvincing.

1️⃣ Compile time of my CLI reached 19 minutes:

[671/671] Linking mobile-cli
Build complete! (1137.97s)

2️⃣ The size of the CLI was 348M.

3️⃣ The command I wrote crashed because the API returned values that were not included in the OpenAPI spec.

Not a great 1st experience. 💻
items.content_text:
I gave [`swift-openapi-generator`](https://github.com/apple/swift-openapi-generator) a try to interact with Apple's own [App Store Connect API](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/appstoreconnectapi). The result was… unconvincing.

1️⃣ Compile time of my CLI reached 19 minutes:

```sh
[671/671] Linking mobile-cli
Build complete! (1137.97s)
```

2️⃣ The size of the CLI was 348M.

3️⃣ The command I wrote crashed because the API returned values that were not included in the OpenAPI spec.

Not a great 1st experience. 💻

items.content_html:
Le résumé de la victoire du Real Madrid face à Almeria de BeIN fait plus de 18 minutes. Il y est beaucoup question de VAR et d’arbitrage. De douloureux souvenirs de polémiques sur la façon dont est arbitré le Real m’avait conditionné à être scandalisé par ces nouvelles décisions controversées. C’est le piège de ce qu’on appelle le biais de confirmation. Pourtant, au bout de ces 18 minutes, je ressens de la compassion pour Almeria, tout en comprenant (presque) toutes les décisions de l’arbitre, surtout après avoir vérifié que “la limite supérieure du bras coïncide avec le bas de l’aisselle”.

Ceci dit, la VAR est malade. Ça pourrait être super, mais c’est trop lent, trop opaque et trop arbitraire. Le football pourrait s’inspirer de la NBA en donnant le micro aux arbitres et en accordant aux entraîneurs un contre-pouvoir avec des challenges vidéo. Votez pour moi à la prochaine élection de la FIFA !

#233 ⚽️
items.content_text:
Le [résumé](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jIRQSYR1R-0) de la victoire du Real Madrid face à Almeria de BeIN fait plus de 18 minutes. Il y est beaucoup question de VAR et d'arbitrage. De [douloureux souvenirs](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P0Agt2Ilhfc) de polémiques sur la façon dont est arbitré le Real m'avait conditionné à être scandalisé par ces nouvelles décisions controversées. C'est le piège de ce qu'on appelle le [biais de confirmation](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biais_de_confirmation). Pourtant, au bout de ces 18 minutes, je ressens de la compassion pour Almeria, tout en comprenant (presque) toutes les décisions de l'arbitre, surtout après avoir vérifié que [“la limite supérieure du bras coïncide avec le bas de l'aisselle”](https://www.theifab.com/fr/laws/latest/fouls-and-misconduct/#direct-free-kick). 

Ceci dit, la VAR est malade. Ça pourrait être super, mais c'est trop lent, trop opaque et trop arbitraire. Le football pourrait s'inspirer de la NBA en [donnant le micro aux arbitres](https://www.youtube.com/shorts/MPfny3f1LCY) et en accordant aux entraîneurs un contre-pouvoir avec des [challenges vidéo](https://trashtalk.co/la-regle-du-challenge-en-nba/). Votez pour moi à la prochaine élection de la FIFA ! 

[#233](https://www.statium.app/newsletter/posts/newsletter-233) ⚽️

items.content_html: Jekyll still has a pulse. Should I reconsider moving on? Probably not. Since Ruby is not as needed for iOS development as it used to (CocoaPods being replaced by SPM, fastlane being replaced by Xcode Cloud), it became my 3rd language. Soon to be 4th if I hold on to my resolution to learn Rust this year. I also found out about Astro, which is a good mix between Jekyll and going full on Remix. 💻
items.content_text: Jekyll still has [a pulse](https://jekyllrb.com/news/2023/12/27/jekyll-4-3-3-released/). Should I reconsider [moving on](https://dirtyhenry.micro.blog/2023/08/06/writing-on-the.html)? Probably not. Since Ruby is not as needed for iOS development as it used to (CocoaPods being replaced by SPM, fastlane being replaced by Xcode Cloud), it became my 3rd language. Soon to be 4th if I hold on to my resolution to learn Rust this year. I also found out about [Astro](https://astro.build/), which is a good mix between Jekyll and going full on Remix. 💻

C’est cette chanson [To The End (La Comédie)] et pas une autre qui m’a convaincu du talent particulier de Damon Albarn, alors que Blur, jusque-là je le confesse, me laissait assez froid peut-être parce que je connaissais et aimais trop les groupes anglais dont Blur s’inspirait. C’est un peu le problème quand on commence à devenir vieux, ce qui était déjà mon cas dans les années 90, on commence à comparer la musique du moment à celle d’avant et c’est une position dont il n’est pas facile de sortir si on veut continuer à découvrir et à aimer de nouvelles choses.

— Michka Assayas

Pas mieux. 🎵

items.content_html:
Lors de la défaite face au Real Madrid en demie-finale de Supercoupe d’Espagne, Antoine Griezmann est devenu le meilleur buteur de l’histoire de l’Atletico Madrid. 174 buts. De quoi faire une vidéo de highlights bien plus longue que celle de Ouédec au PSG.

Blague à part, malgré sa simplicité, le nombre de buts marqués par un joueur fait partie des data. Et, pour revenir sur ce sujet, ce record est un indicateur que, malgré son escapade au Barça, Griezmann est une légende du club. Souvent les joueurs les plus aimés des clubs sont aussi ceux qui y ont disputé le plus grand nombre de matchs. Comme quoi y’a pas que les anti-data qui ont des sentiments, et les anti-data n’ont pas le monopole du cœur.

#230 ⚽️
items.content_text:
Lors de la défaite face au Real Madrid en demie-finale de Supercoupe d’Espagne, **Antoine Griezmann** est devenu le [meilleur buteur de l’histoire](https://www.lequipe.fr/Football/Actualites/Antoine-griezmann-devient-seul-le-meilleur-buteur-de-l-histoire-de-l-atletico-de-madrid/1441432) de l’Atletico Madrid. 174 buts. De quoi faire une vidéo de highlights bien plus longue que celle de Ouédec au PSG. 

Blague à part, malgré sa simplicité, le nombre de buts marqués par un joueur fait partie des _data_. Et, pour [revenir sur ce sujet](https://www.statium.app/newsletter/posts/newsletter-228), ce record est un indicateur que, malgré son escapade au Barça, Griezmann est une légende du club. Souvent les joueurs les plus aimés des clubs sont aussi ceux qui y ont disputé le plus grand nombre de matchs. Comme quoi y'a pas que les anti-data [qui ont des sentiments](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fgg0-Px3CFk), et les anti-data n'ont pas [le monopole du cœur](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y8vfxuwtr4o).

[#230](https://www.statium.app/newsletter/posts/newsletter-230) ⚽️

items.content_html:
J’ai regardé une masterclass de Kevin de Bruyne publiée par Manchester City où le milieu belge partage sa science de la passe. Je la recommande, mais un passage m’a fait grincer des dents, où le bon Kevin glisse un petit taquet à ce qu’on appelle les data :

Pass completion is a word that I don’t care about and I will never care about.

En gros, les taux de réussite de passe, il s’en fiche, et il s’en fichera toujours. Certes, Kevin de Bruyne est seulement dans le 7ème percentile en taux de réussite de passe donc peut-être que ses coachs lui rabattent les oreilles avec ça. Cependant, il peut s’en fiche seulement parce qu’il est exceptionnel dans les autres catégories statistiques de passe.

C’est comme un millionnaire qui dirait qu’il s’en fiche de tenir un budget.

Pour être honnête, Kevin nuance un peu la chose ensuite, mais c’est cet extrait qui a été retenu lors du montage comme extrait de début de vidéo pour attirer le chaland (ça a un nom cette technique ?). Bref, coup de gueule contre les critiques à l’emporte-pièce contre les data du foot.

#228 ⚽️

> Pass completion is a word that I don't care about and I will never care about.

En gros, les taux de réussite de passe, il s'en fiche, et il s'en fichera toujours. Certes, Kevin de Bruyne est seulement dans [le 7ème percentile en taux de réussite de passe](https://fbref.com/en/players/e46012d4/Kevin-De-Bruyne) donc peut-être que ses coachs lui rabattent les oreilles avec ça. Cependant, il peut s'en fiche seulement parce qu'il est exceptionnel dans les autres catégories statistiques de passe. 

C'est comme un millionnaire qui dirait qu'il s'en fiche de tenir un budget.

Pour être honnête, Kevin nuance un peu la chose ensuite, mais c'est cet extrait qui a été retenu lors du montage comme extrait de début de vidéo pour attirer le chaland (ça a un nom cette technique ?). Bref, coup de gueule contre les critiques à l'emporte-pièce contre les data du foot.

items.content_html: Le tirage au sort de l’Euro 2024 a eu lieu. La France sera dans le groupe de l’Autriche, des Pays-Bas, et du vainqueur des barrages entre le Pays de Galles (29è au classement FIFA), la Pologne (31è), la Finlande (59è) ou l’Estonie (122è) qui aura lieu en mars. Que vaut-il mieux alors ? Souhaiter la qualification de l’Estonie, a priori plus faible équipe des 4 ? Ou celle du Pays de Galles ou de la Pologne pour se mettre au niveau ? #219 ⚽️

items.content_html: I love open-source code, but when I come across something that needs improvement in an open-source repository, I sometimes hesitate to point it out because I don’t want to be seen as overly critical or ungrateful. However, I recently felt it was the right thing to do when I raised the issue that vapor-community/bcrypt may no longer be relevant in a somewhat positive manner. Most importantly, I want to express my gratitude to @0xTim@hachyderm.io for their time and dedication to the Swift Server Workgroup. 💻
items.content_text: I love open-source code, but when I come across something that needs improvement in an open-source repository, I sometimes hesitate to point it out because I don't want to be seen as overly critical or ungrateful. However, I recently felt it was the right thing to do when I raised the issue that [`vapor-community/bcrypt`](https://github.com/vapor-community/bcrypt) may no longer be relevant in a [somewhat positive manner](https://github.com/vapor-community/bcrypt/issues/11#issuecomment-1786965734). Most importantly, I want to express my gratitude to [@0xTim@hachyderm.io](https://micro.blog/0xTim@hachyderm.io) for their time and dedication to the Swift Server Workgroup. 💻

items.content_html: The NYT asks if people really need to shower every day. I am really glad to read this. I stopped showering every day a couple of years ago. Why? Saving water, energy, and… I really feel like I don’t need to since I started wearing clothes that don’t get smelly as fast as cotton (such as merino wool or technical fabrics like Uniqlo’s Heattech). 🌱

items.content_html: Bandcamp Schadenfreude. I was offered a deal to become an employee for Bandcamp back in 2011. Then the deal was off for reasons that didn’t make sense. Since then, I had mixed feelings: I liked the product as a listener, not so much as a musician, and I resent founders and managers from then — I know I shouldn’t but I do — and I am not sure they are genuinely nice people. 💻
items.content_text: [Bandcamp Schadenfreude](https://pxlnv.com/linklog/worrying-about-bandcamp/). I was offered a deal to become an employee for Bandcamp back in 2011. Then the deal was off for reasons that didn't make sense. Since then, I had mixed feelings: I liked the product as a listener, not so much [as a musician](https://thelivingstonesipresume.bandcamp.com/), and I resent founders and managers from then — [I know I shouldn't](https://dailystoic.com/you-cant-resent-them/) but I do — and I am not sure they are genuinely nice people. 💻

items.title: Writing on the web post-Jekyll, Ghost edition
items.content_html:
Jekyll does not seem to do well. Despite being used by GitHub for GitHub pages, largely used plugins from the community — such as jekyll-assets, — are falling behind Jekyll 4 or the end of life of Ruby 2.

Ghost has very convincing pros: it is easy, fast and beautiful. It also has everything one can need fully integrated when you just start publishing.

But for a technical person such like me, who has an history of web publishing behind, it also has major cons:

  • MySQL over PostgreSQL. I already run a PostgreSQL DB. I don’t want to run another one;
  • All the built-ins (SEO, analytics) are lost when Ghost is used as a headless CMS;
  • Poor markdown support: line breaks are preserved in posts;
  • Lack of control over the HTML that is being produced;
  • No support of multiple websites for small publishers.

As such, Ghost does not sound like a good CMS solution for me. To be continued. 💻

items.content_html:
🎸 I fell in some intense Interpol nostalgia these last weeks. And i learnt how to play Say Hello to the Angels on the guitar. I also tried to understand how “it works” in terms of music theory.

Most of the guitar resources online lack interactivity and visual cues (even videos, which mostly show narrators speaking).

I wonder if there is an unexplored way to write nice interactive blog posts about learning how songs are constructed.

items.content_html: 👨‍💻 Yesterday, I pulled out my Sortmash iOS app code off dusty shelves as I needed to sort a large amount of data by order of preference — namely my Sorare cards 🤦‍♂️ — and it was a very fun experience. Exploring a pre-ARC Objective-C with embedded dependencies — TouchJSON and ASIHTTPRequest — felt like traveling in time, and made me so grateful of where we stand now. Making the code run again was surprisingly easy but visually very buggy since the code was from an era where iPhone and iPad had each a unique screen size.

items.content_html: 🍿 I am inspired by the ability of young children to watch the same movie over and over again during a short period of time. These days, it’s Robin Hood and Beauty and the Beast. I now tend to watch movies that I have watched already. I like how a movie you watched 2 or 3 times can become familiar, the same way you can get very familiar with a music album.

items.content_text: 🎧 Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, via [his excellent newsletter](https://substack.com/profile/1151098-kareem-abdul-jabbar), made me discover [*At Seventeen* by Janis Ian](https://song.link/i/1546129207). I knew the tune because it was [adapted in French](https://song.link/fr/i/272504370) (quite poorly I now realize) but the original lyrics are much more powerful and Janis is such a great singer that I now see the song through a much more flattering light.
